O HHO TS-1 −0.544 0.405 TS-2 −0.751 0.383 Synthesis of dimethyl carbonate by urea alcoholysis over Zn/Al bi-functional catalysts Xiaomin Wu a b Min Kang a b Yanlong Yin a b Feng Wang a Ning Zhao a ⁎ Fukui Xiao a Wei Wei c ⁎ Yuhan Sun a d a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China c Center for Greenhouse Gas and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 201210, PR China Center for Greenhouse Gas and Environmental Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 201210 PR China d CAS Key Lab of Low-Carbon Conversion Science and Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 201210, PR China CAS Key Lab of Low-Carbon Conversion Science and Engineering, Shanghai Advanced Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 201210 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 0351 4049612; fax: +86 0351 4041153. Graphical abstract Zn/Al mixed oxides (ZAO) were prepared via thermal decomposition of hydrotalcite-type precursors derived from urea precipitation. Specially, ZAO catalysts with a Zn/Al molar ratio of 4:1 exhibited high dimethyl carbonate (DMC) yield (∼36.5%) when utilized for the DMC synthesis from urea and methanol. The XRD, IR, TPD and computational analysis revealed that the formation of ZnAl2O4 spinel significantly modified the surface acidity and basicity of ZAO catalysts, which were beneficial for the DMC synthesis. We thus opened up a bi-functional mechanism that urea and methanol were respectively activated on the weak acidic and basic sites, advancing the DMC synthesis synergistically. Keywords Dimethyl carbonate Urea alcoholysis Zn/Al mixed oxides Acidity and basicity Metal isocyanato group 1 Introduction As a versatile and environmentally-benign chemical reagent, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) can be applied in methylation and carbonylation to substitute the toxic methyl halides, dimethyl sulfate and phosgene [1–3]. DMC also can be used as green solvent [4], electrolyte for lithium ion battery and oxygenated fuel additive [5]. Currently, the commercialized DMC synthesis processes are based on either the oxy-carbonylation of methanol or transesterification of cyclic carbonate [6]. The former suffers from harsh reaction conditions and catalysts deactivation while the availability of raw material (propylene oxide or ethylene oxide) greatly limits the economics for the latter [7]. Consequently, DMC synthesis by urea alcoholysis, as a green and economical process, is drawing much more interest in the field [8–10]. Typically, urea firstly reacts with methanol to generate methyl carbamate (MC), which further reacts with methanol as the rate-control step to form DMC [11]. Unfortunately, by-reactions including DMC decomposition and N-methyl methyl carbamate (MMC) formation, unavoidably reduce the DMC yield and selectivity [12]. Therefore, developing an excellent catalyst with high activity and selectivity is highly desirable and a big challenge for DMC synthesis. Many catalysts for the DMC synthesis by urea alcoholysis have been reported in the past. Currently, zinc has been proved to be the active component toward the DMC synthesis because its weak acidity/basicity effectively promotes the activation of urea and methanol. Zhao et al. have reported that ZnCl2 showed the highest DMC yield among various zinc compounds, ascribing to activation of urea on acidic sites of ZnCl2 [11]. However, it is noticeable that the active ZnO and metal salt dissolve in methanol, unfavorable for the separation of products with the catalysts [13]. Thereby, the purpose of the present research is to develop an efficient heterogeneous bi-functional catalyst for the DMC synthesis. In our work, heterogeneous and stable ZAO catalysts have been fabricated via thermal decomposition of hydrotalcite-type precursors. ZAO-4(1073K) catalyst presented the highest DMC yield (∼36.5%) when employed in the DMC synthesis. The XRD, FT-IR, TPD and computational analysis revealed that the formation of ZnAl2O4 spinel significantly tuned the surface acidity and basicity of ZAO catalysts, which were beneficial for the DMC synthesis. Therefore, we proposed a plausible mechanism that urea and methanol were simultaneously activated on ZAO catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation ZAO catalysts were prepared by thermal decomposition of hydrotalcite-type precursors. The Zn/Al hydrotalcite-like layered precursors was prepared by urea precipitation [14]. Typically: urea was dissolved in a solution of 0.12mol/L of Al (NO3)3·9H2O and 0.48mol/L of Zn (NO3)2·6H2O to reach a urea/metal ion molar ratio of 3.3. The solution was then refluxed at 373K with stirring for 36h. The obtained precipitate was separated from the mother solution, washed with 0.1M sodium carbonate in order to remove the residue nitrate ions with carbonate ions. The solid was then washed with de-ionized water and dried at 373K for 12h, followed by calcination in air at 1073K for 4h. The prepared catalysts were denoted as ZAO (e.g. ZAO-4(1073K) stands for the Zn/Al catalyst with feed molar ratio of 4 and calcination temperature of 1073K). Because calcination of hydrotalcite-type precursors always led to the formation of a mixture of ZnAl2O4 spinel and the oxide of divalent cation, a pure ZnAl2O4 spinel was obtained by selective leaching of ZnO from sample ZAO-3(1073K). Typically, 5g of ZAO-3(1073K) solid was added to 50mL of NaOH (5M) and kept for 48h at 333K under agitation. The resulting suspension was centrifuged to collect the precipitate, which was further washed with de-ionized water and then dried at 353K overnight [15]. The samples obtained were labeled as ZnAl2O4. 2.2 Catalytic test The catalytic performance for DMC synthesis was carried out in a stainless steel autoclave with a magnetic stirrer. Typically, 6.0g urea, 64g methanol and 0.5g catalyst were charged into the reactor, further heated to 453K and kept at 453K for 10h. The reactor was then cooled down to room temperature. The product was analyzed by gas chromatograph (GC) with thermal conductivity detector (TCD) detector equipped with Agilent HP-Plot u column. 2.3 Characterization The Infrared Spectroscopy (IR) was recorded with a Nicolet Nexus 470 Fourier Transform instrument with KBr pellet method. 15mg test sample was pressed to an Φ 13mm self-supporting pellet and placed in the in situ FT-IR apparatus. The sample was introduced with reactant and then heated to the desired temperature for IR spectra measurement. The spectra were collected at a resolution of 4cm−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed on a Panalytical X’Pert Pro X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation, in the step mode (0.0167°, 10s) in the 2θ range of 10–80°. The morphology of the powder was examined using a FETXL30 S-FEG scanning electron microscope (SEM) with an accelerating voltage of 10.00kV. The elemental analysis of Zn/Al mixed oxides was determined by an inductively coupled plasma (ICP) emission spectrometer (Perkin–Elmer ICP OPTIMA-3000) and an Elemental Analyzer (Vario EL III). The surface area of samples was determined with the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method by N2 adsorption–desorption at liquid nitrogen temperature 77.30K, using a Micromeritics Tristar 3000 instrument. Acidity type and acidity strength distribution of the investigated materials was evaluated by temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) according to the following procedure: sample (200mg) was heated at 873K under argon atmosphere for 30min, cooling in argon to room temperature, adsorption of pure ammonia at 298K for 20min, purging with argon at 298K for 0.5h to remove physically adsorbed ammonia, TPD was measured using Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 chemisorptions Analyzer in the temperature range of 298–823K with the heating rate of 10K/min. The distribution of basic sites was determined by temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of CO2 pre-adsorbed at ambient temperature. Typical procedure: 100mg sample was treated in argon at 873K for 0.5h and exposed to CO2 flow for 20min at room temperature. Weakly adsorbed CO2 was removed by passing argon over the sample at room temperature and after that the temperature was increased to 873K at the rate of 10K/min. The concentration of CO2 in the effluent was measured using the Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 chemisorptions Analyzer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization Fig. 1a compared XRD patterns of ZAO catalysts calcined at different temperature with Zn/Al molar ratio of 4. Only ZnO diffraction peaks were observed when ZAO hydrotalcite treated at low temperatures (623 and 873K). New diffraction peaks belonging to ZnAl2O4 appeared concurrently when the calcination temperatures were further heated to 1073 and 1273K [16]. The XRD profiles of ZAO samples with different Zn/Al molar ratios were further evaluated (Fig. 1b). The XRD patterns were quite different with respect to changed Zn/Al molar ratios. The catalyst consisted of only ZnAl2O4 spinel as the molar ratio of Zn/Al was less than 0.5, or ZnO and ZnAl2O4 spinel yielded together. The results revealed that low Zn content and high calcination temperature benefited the formation of ZnAl2O4 spinel, which was favorable to stabilize the ZAO catalysts. Table 1 displayed the tuned Zn/Al molar ratios and BET surface areas of ZAO catalysts. Entries 5–11 disclosed that the Zn/Al molar ratio of the catalysts were less than that of feed ratio, which was caused by the greater affinity of Al3+ ions to the precipitation than Zn2+ ions. As a result, Zn2+ was partially retained in the mother solutions during preparation of precursors [17]. The BET surface area of catalyst was raised from 34.0m2/g of ZAO-4(623K) to 55.7m2/g of ZAO-4(873K) along with an increase from 623 to 873K. It was owed to the formation of loose catalyst structure, which was attributed to the destruction of precursor lamellar shape. However, BET surface area significantly decreased to 9.8m2/g when the temperature reached to 1273K due to the aggregation of crystals. Remarkably, BET surface area of catalyst was up to 142m2/g with a Zn/Al molar ratio of 0.21 since Al effectively suppressed the coalescence of ZnO (Entries 5–7). After removal of ZnO from ZAO-3(1073K), ZnAl2O4 showed a higher BET surface area of 49.5m2/g, exposing more acidic–basic active sites. 3.2 Catalytic performance The prepared ZAO catalysts were utilized to catalyze DMC synthesis (Table 1). Heterogeneous ZAO catalysts exhibited enhanced catalytic performance and ZAO-4(1073K) sample presented the best DMC yield (36.5%, Entry 10). Noticeably, catalysts with Zn/Al molar ratio less than 0.5 displayed poor activity toward DMC synthesis (Entries 5 and 6), owing to the formation of stable ZnAl2O4, consistent with XRD characterization. The catalytic activity remarkably increased when the Zn/Al molar ratio was more than 0.5, ascribing to the synergistic effect between ZnO and ZnAl2O4 in ZAO catalysts. Furthermore, the DMC yield reached to the highest level at calcination temperature of 1073K. According to previous reports, ZnO as active component generally enhanced the production of DMC. However, pure ZnO catalyst exhibited a well performance (∼29.5%, Entry 2) owing to its homogeneous dissolution. Obviously, ZAO-6(1073K) catalyst presented lower DMC yield than that of ZAO-4(1073K) (Entries 10 and 12). The phenomenon also illuminated that the capability of ZnAl2O4 spinel for stabilizing ZnO led to an optional ratio of Zn/Al mixed oxide catalysts, attributing to the synergistic effect between ZnO and ZnAl2O4. In order to further identify the catalytic activity of prepared catalysts, a series of comparative experiments were conducted. As shown in Table 2 , acidic catalysts such as γ-ZrP and Zn-γ-ZrP showed poor catalytic activity (Entries 2 and 3). Analogously, MgO and CaO as basic catalysts (Entries 4 and 5) also exhibited lower DMC yield. However, ZnO and ZnCl2 (Entries 6 and 7) possessing both acidic and basic activity sites have highly enhanced performance up to 29.5% and 21.7%, implying a synergy effect between acidic and basic activity sites. Unfortunately, the homogeneous dissolution of ZnO and ZnCl2 in reaction solution brought about serious problem for the separation of DMC and the recycling of catalysts. Regarding the crucial demand for stable and efficient catalysts, ZAO-4(1073K) was prepared and addressed better DMC yield up to 36.5% far more than single acidic or basic catalysts. Meaningfully, ZAO-4(1073K) as a heterogeneous catalyst also displayed recycling stability that was feasible to be applied in fixed-bed reactor. 3.3 Catalyst stability The regeneration of catalyst was performed by washing the used ZAO-4(1073K) sample with methanol, followed by calcination at 1073K for 2h. The catalytic activity of ZAO-4(1073K) could be recovered despite a little decrease of DMC yield, which was caused by the little leaching of ZnO during the reaction (Fig. 2 ). It was noticed from XRD patterns (Fig. 3 ) that ZnO diffraction peaks decreased after several repeated ZAO-4(1073K) catalyst, while ZnAl2O4 spinel diffraction peaks remained unchanged. Herein, ZAO-4(1073K) catalyst showed better catalytic stability and DMC yield referred to the pure ZnO sample. 3.4 Synergistic effect between ZnO and ZnAl2O4 spinel determined by TPD The surface acidity of ZAO samples was investigated through NH3-TPD analysis (Fig. 4(A)). Firstly, the high temperature with ZnO peak of NH3-TPD (line a) was similar to the peak in the He-TPD suggesting that it was due to decomposition of the catalyst surface [20]. The dissolution of ZnO altered the quantity and quality of catalyst acidity, generating high DMC catalysis activity. For ZnAl2O4 spinel, both weak and strong acidic sites were observed, which, however, strong acidic sites were unfavorable to the urea and MC desorption. In spite of large acidic sites on ZAO-0.5(1073K), the desorbed peaks shifted to higher temperatures (460 and 578K), certainly unfavorable for the desorption of activated substrates [21]. Contrasting with pure Al2O3 and ZnAl2O4, ZAO-4(1073K) displayed a broad peak at 445K, elucidating an abundant distribution of weak acidic sites that manifested the highest DMC yield [22]. Additionally, ZAO-6(1073K) had less acidic sites at 445K than ZAO-4(1073K), resulting in lower activity. These results further confirmed the synergistic effect between ZnO and ZnAl2O4, and ZAO-4(1073K) acquired the optimal Zn/Al molar ratio. The surface basicity of catalysts was examined by CO2-TPD test. As illustrated in Fig. 4B, the intensity of weak basicity of ZAO catalysts was considerably enhanced by the introduction of Al. The complex CO2-TPD profiles suggested that several basic sites available on ZAO catalysts. Three CO2 desorption peaks were located at 350, 426 and 544K, representing bicarbonates on weak basic OH group (α-peak, low temperature), bidendate carbonates on Al-O site pairs (β-peak, intermediate temperature), and unidendate carbonates on strongly basic surface O2− anions (γ-peak, high-temperature), respectively (Fig. 4B, line b) [23,24]. Moreover, the intensity of α-peak for ZAO catalysts notably strengthened than pure ZnAl2O4 spinel. Accompanying the higher content of Zn, the α-peak shifted to lower temperature, whereas β-peak and γ-peak decreased. As a result of facile methanol-adsorption and methoxy-desorption from weak basic sites, the highest DMC yield was thus obtained on ZAO-4(1073K) catalyst. In view of the above results, the acidic/basic sites were significantly changed by the introduction of Al. The formation of abundant weak acidic sites and basic sites on ZAO-4(1073K) catalyst could promote the synthesis of DMC. Furthermore, the synergetic effect between ZnO and ZnAl2O4 in ZAO catalysts involved the stabilizing capability of ZnAl2O4 spinel in ZAO catalysts, which could prevent the leaching of ZnO [25,26]. 3.5 IR spectra between reactants and catalysts 3.5.1 Urea decomposition The urea adsorption and decomposition over ZAO-4(1073K) catalyst at various temperatures were studied by in situ IR (Fig. 5 ). After urea addition, the bands standing for NH, CO and CN stretching vibrations were observed at 3458, 3357, 1685 and 1154cm−1, respectively. The band at 3259cm−1 was assigned to NH stretching vibrations with intermolecular association. Li et al. [27] found that over some metal oxides catalysts, the observation of OCN stretching vibration at ∼2200cm−1 belonged to the metal isocyanato group, originating from the decomposition of urea over high temperature. In the present work, the band of metal isocyanato group (2206cm−1) obviously increased following the decrease of urea peaks when the temperature was elevated (Fig. 5, a–d). The band of metal isocyanato group reached maximum while the bands of urea disappeared at 413K. This temperature was lower than that of pure ZnO as a result of abundant weak acidity in ZAO samples, leading to the higher catalytic activity toward DMC synthesis [27]. Subsequently, metal isocyanato group was decomposed on the surface of catalysts with higher temperature [28]. 3.5.2 Methanol adsorption and desorption The methanol vapor was introduced into the in situ FT-IR apparatus and heated to 453K. After that, the sample was evacuated for several minutes to remove the undissociated methanol (Fig. 6 ). Two new bands at 2934 and 2820cm−1 corresponding to CH asymmetric and symmetrical stretching vibrations were clearly visible over ZAO-4(1073K) catalyst, which indicated the adsorption of methoxyl group on the surface of ZAO catalysts [29,30]. It was well known that methoxyl group was occur when methanol reacted with the surface hydroxyl group of some metal oxides, releasing a molecular of H2O [31,32]. In this work, the IR spectra on ZnAl2O4 spinel and ZAO-4(1073K) were further compared to study the stability of methoxyl group after exposing to air. With respect to ZnAl2O4 spinel, the bands at 2934 and 2820cm−1 did not varied after exposure (Fig. 6a). However, for ZAO-4(1073K) catalyst, the bands at 2934 and 2820cm−1 decreased and eventually disappeared after exposure for 1h. The reason was that methoxyl group was completely substituted by H2O molecule, bringing about the formation of hydroxyl group (Fig. 6b, line c) [32,33]. These in situ IR spectra clearly revealed that the presence of abundant weak basic sites on the surface of ZAO-4(1073K) facilitated the desorption of methoxyl group, promoting the DMC synthesis. 3.5.3 MC adsorption The adsorption of MC over various catalysts was also investigated (Table 3 ). For pure MC, the bands corresponding to CO stretching vibrations, NH stretching vibrations, CH flexural vibrations and CN stretching vibrations were observed at 1681, 1611, 1456 and 1367cm−1, respectively. Meaningly, the CO stretching vibrations of MC adsorbed over some catalysts were much different from pure MC. The CO stretching vibrations of MC adsorbed on ZnO, ZAO-4(1073K) and ZnAl2O4 shifted from 1681cm−1 to 1703, 1705 and 1712cm−1, respectively. The alterations pointed out the interaction of the nitrogen lone-pair electron in MC with acidic sites of ZAO catalysts. The strength of MC adsorbed over catalyst to form N-M was in the order: ZnAl2O4 >ZAO-4(1073K)>ZnO. 3.6 Computational analysis Theoretical studies have also been performed to achieve a mechanistic insight into the DMC synthesis. Due to the complexity of mixed oxides preparation processes, it is difficult to confirm the location of the dopant atom. So in this article, we only assume that the Al atom gets trapped into the structure of ZnO. The ZnO surface model applied here is discribed in the literature [34]. A (3×2)-ZnO ( 10 1 ¯ 0 ) surface super cell with three double layers is taken. The dopant Al atom replaces one Zn atom for every unit cell in the first layer of ZnO. To highlight the relationship between catalysts and reactants, the possible pathways of the DMC synthesis over ZAO ( 10 1 ¯ 0 ) surfaces were investigated [35]. The rate-limiting step was the reaction between MC on unsaturated surface acidic sites and MeOH adsorbed on basic sites. The DFT calculations of the Mulliken electric charge of the MC molecule adsorbed on catalyst surfaces were used by the Dmol3 program available in Materials studio 3.2 package (Table 4 ). M4 showed the best negative electric charge in the N site of MC (−0.603) among free MC (−0.406) and other binding methods. Herein, it was more possible to form the NM bond on ( 10 1 ¯ 0 ) surfaces while MC interacted with ZAO catalysts. The results of DFT calculations of the Mulliken electric charge of MeOH adsorbed on catalyst surfaces were also shown in Table 5 . The Mulliken electric charge of MeOH adsorbed on ZAO surfaces (TS-2, −0.751) was higher than that on ZnO surfaces (TS-1, −0.544). Methanol was thus not dissociated on ZnO surfaces (TS-1). Whereas, the dissociation of methanol on the surface of ZAO were encouraged upon introduction of Al into the ZnO. The dissociative adsorption of OM bond afterward promoted the synthesis of the desired product, which was in accordance with the experimental results. 3.7 Mechanism for DMC synthesis by urea alcoholysis With respect to the experimental and computational results, a plausible bi-functional mechanism for the DMC synthesis from urea and methanol over ZAO catalysts was proposed. Acidic sites decomposed urea to metal isocyanato group while the methoxyl group was yielded from methanol over basic sites (Scheme 1 ). As a result of strongly electron-withdrawing oxygen atom of metal isocyanato group, the lone-pair electrons of methoxyl group attacked the carbon atom of MNCO group, whereas the N atom of metal isocyanato group seized the H atom of methoxyl group. The intermediate a was thus generated. The chemical bonds of MN and OH of intermediate a broke, and then methyl carbamate (MC) formed accompanied by the regeneration of catalysts. Subsequently, MC via its N atom was further bound to acidic sites of ZAO catalysts and afterward reacted with methoxyl group on the basic sites, bringing about the intermediate b. In the present of exess methanol, intermediate b ultimately dissociated to target DMC and ZAO catalysts were concurrently recovered for fresh catalytic cycle. 4 Conclusions In this work, the Zn/Al mixed oxides with weak acidic and basic sites were prepared via the decomposition of hydrotalcite-type precursors. When bi-functional ZAO catalysts were utilized in the DMC synthesis, the excellent catalytic activity and stability were obtained. Through analysing the relationship between catalytic activities and surface acidic/basic properties, we found that the surface weak acidic and basic sites of ZAO catalysts synergistically promoted the DMC synthesis. Therefore, we proposed a bi-functional catalysis mechanism for DMC synthesis as follows: firstly, urea and methanol were decomposed and activated to produce metal isocyanato group and methoxyl group upon the acidic/basic sites, respectively. MC as intermediate product was then formed through intermolecular reaction on the surface of catalysts. Following the reaction of further activated MC on acidic sites and methoxyl group on the basic sites, the terminal DMC was efficiently synthesized over bi-functional and robust ZAO catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Zn/Al mixed oxides (ZAO) were prepared via thermal decomposition of hydrotalcite-type precursors derived from urea precipitation. Specially, ZAO catalysts with a Zn/Al molar ratio of 4:1 exhibited high dimethyl carbonate (DMC) yield (∼36.5%) when utilized for the DMC synthesis from urea and methanol. The XRD, IR, TPD and computational analysis revealed that the formation of ZnAl2O4 spinel significantly modified the surface acidity and basicity of ZAO catalysts, which were beneficial for the DMC synthesis. We thus opened up a bi-functional mechanism that urea and methanol were respectively activated on the weak acidic and basic sites, advancing the DMC synthesis synergistically.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of dimethyl carbonate by urea alcoholysis over Zn/Al bi-functional catalysts
